Grid layout

We use a 12-column responsive grid to give designers and developers a set of layout tools for building responsive web applications. The grid consists of three essential parts:

  1. Container – Sets max-width and adds outer gutters.
  2. Row – Encapsulates columns and offsets outer gutters.
  3. Column – Holds content and adds gutters on either side.

Below are examples of various ways to use the pre-defined grid classes to create responsive layouts.

Common layouts

Here are examples of some common column layouts, including 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, and 1/4 - 3/4.

Responsive columns

The grid is responsive using the mobile-first approach. So you start by defining the column width for the xs screen size, then again for each screen size where you want the column width to change. If you skip a screen size, it will automatically inherit the size from the next smaller size that was specified. For example, .col-xs-12 .col-md-6 would apply 12 column width to sm screens since the next smaller size is .col-xs-12.

12 columns on XS6 columns on SM4 columns on MD8 columns on LG6 columns on XL

Column Offsets

Grid columns can be offset as needed to shift content or visually center a column. As with everything else in the grid, these offsets can be applied on a per screen size basis.

6 Columns, offset by 3
4 Columns, offset by 4
6 Columns, offset by 6
4 Columns, offset by 8

Push and pull

Columns can be shifted right or left using the .push-* and .pull-* classes. This approach can be used to visually swap the order of columns when you need them to flow A > B for one screen size, but B > A on another. The example below swaps the column order for md screen and larger.
